column1: Thunder Bay is a city in and the seat of Thunder Bay District
column2: Ontario
column3: Canada. It is the most populous municipality in Northwestern Ontario and the second most populous (after Greater Sudbury) municipality in Northern Ontario; its population is 107
column4: 909 according to the 2016 Canada Census

column2: the census metropolitan area of Thunder Bay has a population of 121
column3: 621 and consists of the city of Thunder Bay
column4: the municipalities of Oliver Paipoonge and Neebing
column5: the townships of Shuniah
column6: Conmee
column7: O'Connor
column9: and the Fort William First Nation.

column1: European settlement in the region began in the late 17th century with a French fur trading outpost on the banks of the Kaministiquia River. It grew into an important transportation hub with its port forming an important link in the shipping of grain and other products from western Canada
column2: through the Great Lakes and the Saint Lawrence Seaway
column3: to the east coast. Forestry and manufacturing played important roles in the city's economy. They have declined in recent years
column4: but have been replaced by a "knowledge economy" based on medical research and education. Thunder Bay is the site of the Thunder Bay Regional Health Research Institute.

column1: The city takes its name from the immense Thunder Bay at the head of Lake Superior
column2: known on 18th-century French maps as Baie du Tonnerre (Bay of Thunder). The city is often referred to as the "Lakehead"
column3: or "Canadian Lakehead"
column4: because of its location at the end of Great Lakes navigation on the Canadian side of the border.

column1: European settlement at Thunder Bay began with two French fur trading posts (in 1683 and 1717) which were subsequently abandoned (see Fort William
column2: Ontario). In 1803
column3: the Montreal-based North West Company established Fort William as its mid-continent entrepôt. The fort thrived until 1821 when the North West Company merged with the Hudson's Bay Company
column4: and Fort William was no longer needed.

column2: the Province of Canada began to take an interest in its western extremity. Discovery of copper in the Keweenaw Peninsula of Michigan had prompted a national demand for mining locations on the Canadian shores of Lake Superior. In 1849
column3: French-speaking Jesuits established the Mission de l'Immaculée-Conception (Mission of the Immaculate Conception) on the Kaministiquia to evangelize the Ojibwe. The Province of Canada negotiated the Robinson Treaty in 1850 with the Ojibwa of Lake Superior. As a result
column4: an Indian reserve was set aside for them south of the Kaministiquia River. In 1859–60
column5: the Department of Crown Lands surveyed two townships (Neebing and Paipoonge) and the Town Plot of Fort William for European-Canadian settlement.

column1: Another settlement developed a few miles to the north of Fort William after construction by the federal Department of Public Works of a road connecting Lake Superior with the Red River Colony. The work was directed by Simon James Dawson (see Port Arthur
column2: Ontario). This public works depot or construction headquarters acquired its first name in May 1870 when Colonel Garnet Wolseley named it Prince Arthur's Landing. It was renamed Port Arthur by the Canadian Pacific Railway (CPR) in May 1883.The arrival of the CPR in 1875 sparked a long rivalry between the towns
column3: which did not end until their amalgamation in 1970. Until the 1880s
column4: Port Arthur was a much larger and dynamic community. The CPR
column5: in collaboration with the Hudson's Bay Company
column6: preferred east Fort William
column7: located on the lower Kaministiquia River where the fur trade posts were. Provoked by a prolonged tax dispute with Port Arthur and its seizure of a locomotive in 1889
column8: the CPR relocated all its employees and facilities to Fort William. The collapse of silver mining after 1890 undermined the economy of Port Arthur. It had an economic depression

column1: In the era of Sir Wilfrid Laurier
column2: Thunder Bay began a period of extraordinary growth
column3: based on improved access to markets via the transcontinental railway and development of the western wheat boom. The CPR double-tracked its Winnipeg–Thunder Bay line. The Canadian Northern Railway established facilities at Port Arthur. The Grand Trunk Pacific Railway began construction of its facilities at the Fort William Mission in 1905
column4: and the federal government began construction of the National Transcontinental Railway. Grain elevator construction boomed as the volume of grain shipped to Europe increased. Both cities incurred debt to grant bonuses to manufacturing industries.

column2: the twin cities had modern infrastructures (sewers
column3: potable water supply
column4: street lighting
column5: electric light
column6: etc.) Both Fort William and Port Arthur were proponents of municipal ownership. As early as 1892
column7: Port Arthur built Canada's first municipally-owned electric street railway. Both cities spurned Bell Telephone Company of Canada to establish their own municipally-owned telephone systems in 1902.

column1: The boom came to an end in 1913–1914
column2: aggravated by the outbreak of the First World War. A war-time economy emerged with the making of munitions and shipbuilding. Men from the cities joined the 52nd
column3: 94th
column4: and 141st Battalions of the Canadian Expeditionary Force.

column1: Railway employment was hurt when the federal government took over the National Transcontinental Railway and Lake Superior Division from the Grand Trunk in 1915
column2: and the Canadian Northern Railway in 1918. These were amalgamated with other government-owned railways in 1923 to form the Canadian National Railways. The CNR closed many of the Canadian Northern Railway facilities in Port Arthur. It opened the Neebing yards in Neebing Township in 1922. By 1929
column3: the population of the two cities had recovered to pre-war levels.

column1: The forest products industry has played an important role in the Thunder Bay economy from the 1870s. In the 1880s
column2: Herman Finger established the Pigeon River Lumber Company in the area
column3: and also built the Gunflint and Lake Superior Railroad
column4: but he dissolved the lumber company and moved his operations to The Pas by 1919. Logs and lumber were shipped primarily to the United States. In 1917
column5: the first pulp and paper mill was established in Port Arthur. It was followed by a mill at Fort William
column6: in 1920. Eventually there were four mills operating.

column1: Manufacturing resumed in 1937 when the Canada Car and Foundry Company plant (opened for the manufacture of naval ships and railcars during the late World War I) re-opened to build British aircraft. Now run by Bombardier Transportation
column2: the plant has remained a mainstay of the post-war economy. It has produced forestry equipment and transportation equipment for urban transit systems
column3: such as the Toronto Transit Commission and GO Transit.

column2: the City of Thunder Bay was formed through the merger of the cities of Fort William
column3: Port Arthur
column4: and the geographic townships of Neebing and McIntyre. Its name was the result of a referendum held previously on 23 June 1969
column5: to determine the new name of the amalgamated Fort William and Port Arthur. Officials debated over the names to be put on the ballot
column6: taking suggestions from residents including "Lakehead" and "The Lakehead". Predictably
column7: the vote split between the two
column8: and "Thunder Bay" was the victor. The final tally was "Thunder Bay" with 15
column13: 377.There was more controversy over the selection of a name for the amalgamated city than over whether to amalgamate. A vocal minority of the population preferred "The Lakehead". There was much discussion about other cities in the world that use the word "The" in their names. The area was often referred to as "The Lakehead" before and after amalgamation based on its geographic location. It was seen as the "head" of shipping on the Great Lakes and the "rail head".

column2: beginning with the Trans-Canada Highway and culminating with the opening of Highway 17 (linking Sault Ste Marie to Thunder Bay in 1960)
column3: has significantly diminished railway and shipping activity since the 1970s and 80s. Shipping on the Saint Lawrence Seaway was superseded by trucking on highways. Grain shipping on the Great Lakes to the East has declined substantially in favour of transport to Pacific Coast ports. As a result
column4: many grain elevators have been closed and demolished. The Kaministiquia River was abandoned by industry and shipping.

column1: Thunder Bay has become the regional services centre for Northwestern Ontario with most provincial departments represented. Lakehead University
column2: established through the lobbying of local businesspeople and professionals
column3: has proven to be a major asset. Another upper level institution is Confederation College. The same businessmen and professionals who helped attract the university and college were the driving force(s) behind the political amalgamation of Fort William and Port Arthur in 1970.

column1: The city has an area of 328.48 square kilometres (126.83 sq mi)
column2: which includes the former cities of Fort William and Port Arthur
column3: as well as the former townships of Neebing and McIntyre. The city reflects the settlement patterns of the 19th century and sprawls. Anchoring the west end of the city
column4: the Fort William Town Plot
column5: surveyed in 1859–60
column6: was named West Fort William (or Westfort) in 1888 by the CPR. The land adjoining the lower Kaministiquia River became the residential and central business district of the town and city of Fort William. A large uninhabited area adjoining the Neebing and McIntyre rivers
column7: which became known as Intercity
column8: separated Fort William from the residential and central business district of Port Arthur. At the extreme east of the city
column9: a part of McIntyre Township was annexed to the town of Port Arthur in 1892
column10: forming what later became known as the Current River area.The former Port Arthur section is more typical of the Canadian Shield
column11: with gently sloping hills and very thin soil lying on top of bedrock with many bare outcrops. Thunder Bay
column12: which gives the city its name
column13: is about 22.5 kilometres (14.0 mi) from the Port Arthur downtown to Thunder Cape at the tip of the Sleeping Giant. The former Fort William section occupies flat alluvial land along the Kaministiquia River. In the river delta are two large islands: Mission Island and McKellar Island. Since 1970
column14: the central business districts of Fort William and Port Arthur have suffered a serious decline.  Business and government relocated to new developments in the Intercity area. There has also been substantial residential growth in adjacent areas of the former Neebing and McIntyre townships.

column1: The Thunder Bay area experiences a warm-summer humid continental climate (Köppen: Dfb) and a continental subarctic (Dfc) influence in northeastern areas of the city (including that affected by Lake Superior)
column2: but not necessarily falling in this zone.  This results in warmer summer (or cooler) temperatures and warmer winter temperatures for an area extending inland as far as 16 km. The average daily temperatures range from 17.7 °C (63.9 °F) in July to −14.3 °C (6.3 °F) in January. The average daily high in July is 24.3 °C (75.7 °F) and the average daily high in January is −8.0 °C (17.6 °F). On 10 January 1982
column3: the local temperature in Thunder Bay dropped to −36.3 °C (−33.3 °F)
column4: with a wind speed of 54 km (34 mi) per hour for a wind chill temperature that dipped to −58 °C (−72.4 °F). As a result
column5: it holds Ontario's record for coldest day with wind chill. The highest temperature ever recorded in Thunder Bay was 40.3 °C (104.5 °F) on 7 August 1983. The coldest temperature ever recorded was −43.2 °C (−45.8 °F) on 31 January 1996.The city is quite sunny
column6: with an average of 2
column7: 121 hours of bright sunshine each year
column8: ranging from 268.1 hours in July to 86.2 hours in November. Winters are comparatively dry with the snowfall being very limited and temperatures much colder than in Houghton
column10: on the U.S. side of the lake
column11: where the climate is marked by heavy lake-effect snow. Thunder Bay has more of a continental climate in comparison.

column2: Thunder Bay was the city with the highest per-capita rate of homicides in Canada. Winnipeg had previously held the distinction of having the highest rate from the years 2007 to 2011. In 2014
column3: the per-capita rate of homicides in Thunder Bay was more than double the 2012 rate
column4: and was over 2.5 times higher than the city with the next highest rate. However
column5: between 2014 and 2015
column6: the crime rate decreased by 6%. This was the second highest decrease in any major Canadian city
column7: behind only Moncton

column1: Thunder Bay is composed of two formerly separate cities: Port Arthur and Fort William. Both still retain much of their distinct civic identities
column2: reinforced by the buffering effect of the Intercity area between them. Port Arthur and Fort William each have their own central business districts and suburban areas. Some of the more well-known neighbourhoods include the Bay and Algoma area
column3: which has a large northern European population centred around the Finnish Labour Temple and the Italian Cultural Centre; Simpson-Ogden and the East End
column4: two of the oldest neighbourhoods in Fort William located north of Downtown Fort William; Intercity
column5: a large business district located between Fort William and Port Arthur; Current River
column6: the northernmost neighbourhood of Port Arthur; and Westfort
column7: the oldest settlement in Thunder Bay. Within city limits are some small rural communities
column8: such as Vickers Heights and North McIntyre
column9: which were located in the former townships of Neebing and McIntyre

column1: The city is governed by a mayor and twelve councillors. The mayor and five of the councillors are elected at large by the whole city. Seven councillors are elected for the seven wards: Current River Ward
column2: McIntyre Ward
column3: McKellar Ward
column4: Neebing Ward
column5: Northwood Ward
column6: Red River Ward
column7: and Westfort Ward.Thunder Bay is represented in the Canadian Parliament by Don Rusnak
column9: both members of the Liberal Party of Canada
column10: and in the Ontario Legislature by Michael Gravelle of the Ontario Liberal Party and Judith Monteith-Farrell on the Ontario New Democratic Party.

column1: Sleeping GiantA large formation of mesas on the Sibley Peninsula in Lake Superior which resembles a reclining giant has become a symbol of the city. Sibley peninsula partially encloses the waters of Thunder Bay
column2: and dominates the view of the lake from the northern section of the city (formerly Port Arthur). The Sleeping Giant also figures on the city's coat of arms and the city flag.

column1: The coat of arms of Thunder Bay
column2: Ontario
column3: is a combination of the coats of arms of both Port Arthur and Fort William
column4: with a unifying symbol—the Sleeping Giant—at the base of the arms.

column1: Corporate logoThe city logo depicts a stylized thunderbird
column2: called Animikii
column3: a statue of which is located at the city's Kaministiquia River Heritage Park. The slogan
column4: Superior by Nature
column5: is a double play on words reflecting the city's natural setting on Lake Superior.

column1: City flagThunder Bay's flag was created in 1972
column2: when mayor Saul Laskin wanted to promote the city by having a distinctive flag. The city held a contest
column3: which Cliff Redden won. The flag has a 1:2 ratio and depicts a golden sky from the rising sun behind the Sleeping Giant
column4: which sits in the blue waters of Lake Superior. The sun is represented by a red maple leaf
column5: a symbol of Canada. Green and gold are Thunder Bay's city colours.

column1: As the largest city in Northwestern Ontario
column2: Thunder Bay is the region's commercial
column3: administrative and medical centre. Many of the city's largest single employers are in the public sector. The City of Thunder Bay
column4: the Thunder Bay Regional Health Sciences Centre
column5: the Lakehead District School Board and the Government of Ontario each employ over 1
column6: 500 people.  Resolute Forest Products is the largest private employer
column7: employing over 1
column10: 400 m2) plant in Thunder Bay which manufactures mass transit vehicles and equipment
column11: employing approximately 800 people. The plant was built by Canadian Car and Foundry to build railway box cars in 1912
column12: began building passenger railcar and transit cars from 1963 onwards Bombardier acquired the facility from UTDC in 1992
column13: which had acquired it from Cancar in 1984.

column1: Lack of innovation by traditional industries
column2: such as forest products
column3: combined with high labour costs have reduced the industrial base of Thunder Bay by close to 60%. The grain trade has declined because of the loss of grain transportation subsidies and the loss of European markets. The gradual transition from shipping by train and boat to shipping by truck
column4: and the Canada–United States Free Trade Agreement have ended Thunder Bay's privileged position as a linchpin in Canadian east–west freight-handling trade. As a result
column5: the city has lost its traditional raison d'être as a break-bulk point. However
column6: in recent years shipments through the port of Thunder Bay have stabilized
column7: and remains an important part of the Saint Lawrence Seaway.In an effort to rejuvenate its economy
column8: the city has been actively working to attract quaternary or "knowledge-based" industries
column9: primarily in the fields of molecular medicine and genomics. The city is home to the western campus of the Northern Ontario School of Medicine
column10: the first medical school to open in Canada in a generation. The city also has a law school.

column2: rail and shipping traffic due to its prime location along major continental transportation routes. The municipally owned Thunder Bay Transit operates 17 routes across the city's urban area. The city is served by the Thunder Bay International Airport
column3: the fourth busiest airport in Ontario by aircraft movements. The main highway through the city is Highway 11/17
column4: a four-lane highway designated as the Thunder Bay Expressway.

column1: The city is an important railway hub
column2: served by both the Canadian National and Canadian Pacific Railway. Passenger rail service to Thunder Bay ended on 15 January 1990
column3: with the cancellation of Via Rail's southern transcontinental service.

column1: Thunder Bay has been a port since the days of the North West Company
column2: which maintained a schooner on Lake Superior. The Port of Thunder Bay is the largest outbound port on the St. Lawrence Seaway System
column3: and the sixth-largest port in Canada. The Thunder Bay Port Authority manages Keefer Terminal
column4: built on a 320
column5: 000 square metre site on Lake Superior.

column1: Thunder Bay has one major hospital
column2: the Thunder Bay Regional Health Sciences Centre. Other health care services include the St. Joseph's Care Group
column3: which operates long-term care centres such as the Lakehead Psychiatric Hospital
column4: St. Joseph's Hospital
column5: and Hogarth Riverview Manor. The Northern Ontario School of Medicine has a campus at Lakehead University. The city is also home to a variety of smaller medical and dental clinics.

column2: there were 107
column3: 909 people residing in Thunder Bay on 10 May 2016
column4: of whom 48.8% were male and 51.2% were female. Residents 19 years of age or younger accounted for approximately 19.9% of the population. People aged by 20 and 39 years accounted for 25.0%
column5: while those between 40 and 64 made up 35.1% of the population. The average age of a Thunder Bayer in May 2016 was 43.3
column6: compared to the average of 41.0 for Canada as a whole.Between the censuses of 2011 and 2016
column7: Thunder Bay's population decreased by 0.1%
column8: compared to an increase of 4.6% for Ontario and 5.0% for Canada. The population density of the city of Thunder Bay averaged 328.6 people per square kilometre
column9: compared with an average of 14.8 for Ontario. The total population has been stagnant or declining since amalgamation in 1970.

column2: Thunder Bay was home to 13
column3: 565 people of Finnish descent
column4: the highest concentration of people of Finnish origin per capita in Canada. Thunder Bay has a large Aboriginal population representing 13.2% of the population
column5: while visible minorities represent 4% of the population.

column1: The 2001 census states that 82% of Thunder Bay residents belonged to a Christian denomination: 39.8% of the total population was Roman Catholic
column2: 39.5% were Protestant
column3: and 2.6% followed other Christian denominations
column4: mostly Eastern Orthodox. Those who followed other religions made up less than 1% of the population
column5: while the remaining 17% were non-religious or did not respond.

column18: some of which allow visitors to search for their own crystals. A 2.74 m (9 ft) statue of Terry Fox is situated at the Terry Fox Memorial and Lookout on the outskirts of the city near the place where he was forced to abandon his run. Other tourists attractions are listed below:

column2: such as the Finnish Labour Temple
column3: Scandinavia House

column1: Thunder Bay is home to a variety of music and performance arts  venues. The Thunder Bay Symphony Orchestra
column2: founded in 1960
column3: is the only professional orchestra between Winnipeg and Toronto
column4: and has 31 full-time and up to 30 extra musicians presenting a full range of classical music. New Music North is vital to the contemporary classical music scene in the city by offering intriguing and novel contemporary chamber music concerts. The largest professional theatre is Magnus Theatre. Founded in 1971
column5: it offers six stage plays each season and is located in the renovated Port Arthur Public School on Red River Road. The Thunder Bay Community Auditorium
column6: which seats 1500
column7: is the primary venue for various types of entertainment.

column1: The Vox Popular Media Arts Festival
column2: established in 2005
column3: is an independent film festival that features local
column4: national
column5: and international films with the theme of "Films for the People." The festival is held in early October at 314 Bay Street in the historic Finnish Labour Temple. Thunder Bay is also home to the North of Superior Film Association (NOSFA). Established in 1992
column6: the NOSFA features monthly screenings of international and Canadian films at the Cumberland Cinema Centre
column7: and organized the annual Northwest Film Fest film festival that attracts several thousand patrons. Two of Thunder Bay's festivals were included in the 2018 list of the 100 best festival compiled by Festivals and Events Ontario: Teddy Bears Picnic and Live on the Waterfront
column8: the former also being recognized as best promotional campaign and sponsor of the year.The Northwestern Ontario Writers Workshop (NOWW)
column10: is the largest of several writing groups based in Thunder Bay. Its mission is "to encourage and promote the development of the writers and literature of Northwestern Ontario". NOWW does this through a number of activities including regular workshops
column13: and other events designed to help and inspire writers in the region. NOWW also hosts an annual LitFest in May which includes an awards presentation to the winners of its international annual writing contest. Past contest judges include a Who's Who of Canadian writers such as Heather O'Neill

Thunder Bay has many places of worship supported by people of a variety of faiths

column1: Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary Church – Ukrainian Orthodox. The original wooden church
column2: built by Ukrainian Orthodox families in 1911/1912

column4: with Orthodox crosses atop the domes.

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church). The church has a family history library open to anyone to research their genealogy.

Evangel Church. Contemporary Pentecostal church with a strong emphasis on children

Thunder Bay's proximity to the wilderness of the Boreal Forest and the rolling hills and mountains of the Canadian Shield allow its residents to enjoy very active lifestyles. The city has hosted several large sporting events including the Summer Canada Games in 1981
column2: the Nordic World Ski Championships in 1995
column3: the Continental Cup of Curling in 2003
column4: and the World Junior Baseball Championship in 2010 & 2017.

column1: Thunder Bay enjoys many recreational facilities. The city operates fifteen neighbourhood community centres
column2: which offer various sporting and fitness facilities as well as seasonal activities such as dances. The city also operates six indoor ice rinks and 84 seasonal outdoor rinks
column3: two indoor community pools and three seasonal outdoor pools as well as a portable pool and two maintained public beaches
column4: several curling sheets
column5: and three golf courses
column6: among others. Listed below are some of the city's major facilities.

column1: Thunder Bay is also home to the National Development Centre – Thunder Bay

column5: owned by Acadia Broadcasting. One additional station
column6: Energy 103/104
column7: targets the Thunder Bay market from transmitters in Kaministiquia and Shuniah. The city receives CBC Radio One as CBQT-FM and CBC Radio 2 as CBQ-FM
column8: at 88.3 FM and 101.7 FM respectively. The French Première Chaîne is available as a repeater of Sudbury-based CBON-FM on 89.3 FM. Lakehead University operates a campus radio station
column11: and CJOA-FM 95.1 broadcasts Christian-oriented programming and is run by a local non-profit group. Thunder Bay Information Radio CKSI-FM is broadcast 24/7 on 90.5 and is also the city's emergency radio station.

column1: Thorold J. Tronrud and A. Ernest Epp (1995) Thunder Bay: From Rivalry to Unity
column2: Thunder Bay Historical Museum Society
